maml:description.maml:para: Used to prompt user to approve running script
In addition to prompt, execution context is shown. Asking for approval helps to let run master script and only execute specific scripts, thus loading only needed rules.

maml:Description.maml:para: If specified the command is considered unsafe, and the default action is then "No"
Prompt title

command:parameter.maml:name: Question

maml:Description.maml:para: Prompt question

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: Do you want to run this script?

command:parameter.maml:name: Accept

maml:Description.maml:para: Prompt help menu for default action

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: Continue with only the next step of the operation

command:parameter.maml:name: Deny

maml:Description.maml:para: Prompt help menu for deny action

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: Skip this operation and proceed with the next operation

maml:Description.maml:para: True if user selects YesToAll. If this is already true, Approve-Execute will bypass the prompt and return true.
true if user selects NoToAll. If this is already true, Approve-Execute will bypass the prompt and return false.
If specified the command is considered unsafe, and the default action is then "No"

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: Do you want to run this script?

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: Skip this operation and proceed with the next operation

maml:Description.maml:para: True if user selects YesToAll. If this is already true, Approve-Execute will bypass the prompt and return true.
true if user selects NoToAll. If this is already true, Approve-Execute will bypass the prompt and return false.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to Approve-Execute
[bool] True if the user wants to continue, false otherwise

maml:description.maml:para: Compare 2 paths for equality or similarity

Compare-Path depending on parameters either checks if 2 paths lead to same location taking into account environment variables, relative path locations and wildcards or it checks if 2 paths are similar which depends on wildcards contained in the input

maml:Description.maml:para: The path which to compare against the reference path
The path against which to compare
if specified perform "loose" comparison: Does not attempt to resolve input paths, and respects wildcards all of which happens after input paths have been expanded off environment variables
If specified performs case sensitive comparison
The path which to compare against the reference path
The path against which to compare
if specified perform "loose" comparison: Does not attempt to resolve input paths, and respects wildcards all of which happens after input paths have been expanded off environment variables
If specified performs case sensitive comparison

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to Compare-Path

maml:description.maml:para: Verify file is correctly encoded
Confirm-FileEncoding verifies target file is encoded as expected. Wrong encoding may return bad data resulting is unexpected behavior

maml:Description.maml:para: Path to the file which to check
Expected encoding
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Path to the file which to check
Expected encoding
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

dev:type.maml:name: [string] One or more paths to file to check
None. Confirm-FileEncoding does not generate any output

maml:description.maml:para: Convert SDDL string to ACL
Convert SDDL strings to ACL entries

maml:Description.maml:para: String array of one or more strings of SDDL syntax
String array of one or more strings of SDDL syntax

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to Convert-SDDLToACL

maml:alert.maml:para: This is experimental function and needs a lot of improvements.

maml:description.maml:para: Get a group of environment variables

Get-EnvironmentVariable gets a predefined group of environment variables. This is useful to verify path patterns, ex. paths for firewall rules must not contain paths with userprofile environment variable.

maml:Description.maml:para: A group of environment variables to get as follows: 1. UserProfile - Environment variables that leads to valid directory in user profile 2. WhiteList - Environment variables which are valid directories 3. BlackList - The opposite of WhiteList 4. All - Whitelist and BlackList together

A group of environment variables to get as follows: 1. UserProfile - Environment variables that leads to valid directory in user profile 2. WhiteList - Environment variables which are valid directories 3. BlackList - The opposite of WhiteList 4. All - Whitelist and BlackList together

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to Get-EnvironmentVariable

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns all environment variables that lead to user profile
Returns all environment variables on computer

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the encoding of a file
Gets the encoding of a file, if the encoding can't be determined, ex. the file contains unicode charaters but no BOM, then by default UTF-8 is assumed.

maml:Description.maml:para: The path of the file to get the encoding of
Default encoding for non ASCII files. The default is set by global variable, UTF8 no BOM for Core or UTF8 with BOM for Desktop edition
The path of the file to get the encoding of
Default encoding for non ASCII files. The default is set by global variable, UTF8 no BOM for Core or UTF8 with BOM for Desktop edition

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to Get-FileEncoding

maml:alert.maml:para: TODO: utf-16LE detected as utf-16 with BOM NOTE: This function is based on (but is not) sample from "Windows PowerShell Cookbook"

maml:description.maml:para: Get a list of windows services involved in rules
Scan all scripts in this repository and get windows service names involved in rules, the result is saved to file and used to verify existence of these services on target system.

maml:Description.maml:para: Root folder name which to scan recursively
Root folder name which to scan recursively

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to Get-NetworkService
None. Get-NetworkService does not generate any output

maml:description.maml:para: Run process and capture output
Run process with or without arguments, set wait time and capture output. If the target process results in an error, error message is formatted and shown in addition to standard output if any.

maml:Description.maml:para: The application or document to start
A collection of command-line arguments to use when starting the application
Number of milliseconds to wait for the associated process to exit Default is 0, which means wait indefinitely
Whether to use the operating system shell to start the process
If specified formats standard output into INFO messages
The application or document to start
A collection of command-line arguments to use when starting the application
Whether to use the operating system shell to start the process
Number of milliseconds to wait for the associated process to exit Default is 0, which means wait indefinitely
If specified formats standard output into INFO messages

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to Get-ProcessOutput
[string] If the "Format" parameter is not specified

maml:alert.maml:para: TODO: Function needs improvements and more test cases TODO: consider renaming to Format-ProcessOutput

maml:description.maml:para: Get .NET outputs of a commandlet or convert to/from type accelerator

Returns .NET output typename of a function or commandlet. When piped, object's output typenames are handled per input. In both cases input can be translated to/from type accelerator. The function fails if output type is not .NET type

maml:Description.maml:para: Target object for which to retrieve output typenames. This is the actual output of some commandlet or function when passed to Get-TypeName, either via pipeline or directly.

When used converts resultant full typename to accelerator. Otherwise if specified with "Name" parameter, converts resultant accelerator to full name. No conversion is done if resultant type already is of desired format.
Commandlet or function name for which to retrieve OutputType attribute value The command name can be specified either as "FUNCTIONNAME" or just FUNCTIONNAME

When used converts resultant full typename to accelerator. Otherwise if specified with "Name" parameter, converts resultant accelerator to full name. No conversion is done if resultant type already is of desired format.

Translate full type name to accelerator or accelerator to full typename. By default converts acceleartors to full typenames. No conversion is done if resultant type already is of desired format. The name of a type can be specified either as a "typename" or [typename] syntax

When used converts resultant full typename to accelerator. Otherwise if specified with "Name" parameter, converts resultant accelerator to full name. No conversion is done if resultant type already is of desired format.
Target object for which to retrieve output typenames. This is the actual output of some commandlet or function when passed to Get-TypeName, either via pipeline or directly.
Commandlet or function name for which to retrieve OutputType attribute value The command name can be specified either as "FUNCTIONNAME" or just FUNCTIONNAME

Translate full type name to accelerator or accelerator to full typename. By default converts acceleartors to full typenames. No conversion is done if resultant type already is of desired format. The name of a type can be specified either as a "typename" or [typename] syntax

When used converts resultant full typename to accelerator. Otherwise if specified with "Name" parameter, converts resultant accelerator to full name. No conversion is done if resultant type already is of desired format.

maml:alert.maml:para: There may be multiple accelerators for same type, for example: Get-TypeName -Name [System.Management.Automation.PSObject] -Accelerator It's possible to rework function to get the exact type if this is desired see being block TODO: Will not work to detect .NET types for formatted or custom data, see Get-FormatData TODO: Will not work for non .NET types because we have no use of it, but should be implemented, see Get-TypeName unit test

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sends typename for each input object down the pipeline

maml:description.maml:para: Set network profile for physical network interfaces
Set network profile for each physical/hardware network interfaces Recommended is "Public" profile for maximum security, unless "Private" is needed

maml:Description.maml:para: Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to Set-NetworkProfile
None. Set-NetworkProfile does not generate any output

maml:alert.maml:para: TODO: It looks like option to change network profile in settings app will be gone after using this function in an elevated prompt

maml:description.maml:para: Take ownership or set permissions on file system or registry object
Set-Permission sets permission or ownership of a filesystem or registry object such as file, folder, registry key or registry item.

maml:Description.maml:para: Resource on which to set ownership or permissions. Valid resources are files, directories, registry keys and registry entries. Environment variables are allowed.
Principal who will be the new owner of a resource. Using this parameter means taking ownership of a resource.
Principal domain such as computer name or authority to which principal applies
If specified, applies specified operations to all subobjects. This parameter is ignored for Leaf objects, such as files or registry entries.
If specified skips prompting for confirmation.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Resource on which to set ownership or permissions. Valid resources are files, directories, registry keys and registry entries. Environment variables are allowed.
Principal to which to grant specified permissions. Using this parameter means setting permissions on a resource.
Principal domain such as computer name or authority to which principal applies
Access control type to either allow or deny specified rights

Defines file system access rights to use for principal when creating access and audit rules. The default includes: ReadAndExecute, ListDirectory and Traverse Where: 1. ReadAndExecute: Read and ExecuteFile 2. Read: ReadData, ReadExtendedAttributes, ReadAttributes, and ReadPermissions.

Inheritance flags specify the semantics of inheritance for access control entries. This parameter is ignored for leaf objects, such as files or or registry entries. This parameter controls the "Applies to" column in advanced security dialog The default is "This folder, subfolders and files"

Specifies how Access Control Entries (ACEs) are propagated to child objects. These flags are significant only if inheritance flags are present, (when Inheritance is not "None") This parameter is ignored for leaf objects, such as files or or registry entries. This parameter affects the "Applies to" column in advanced security dialog

If set, protect the specified access rules from inheritance. The default is to allow inheritance. Protected access rules cannot be modified by parent objects through inheritance. This parameter controls the "Enable/Disable Inheritance" button in advanced security dialog

If set, preserve inherited access rules, which become explicit rules. The default is to remove inherited access rules. This parameter is ignored if Protected is not set. This parameter controls choices offered after "Enable/Disable Inheritance" button.
If specified, applies specified operations to all subobjects. This parameter is ignored for Leaf objects, such as files or registry entries.

If specified, removes all explicit access rules and keeps only inherited. if "Protected" parameter is specified inherited rules are removed as well. If "Protected" is specified with "PreserveInheritance", then the inherited rules become explicit rules and everything else is removed.
If specified skips prompting for confirmation.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Resource on which to set ownership or permissions. Valid resources are files, directories, registry keys and registry entries. Environment variables are allowed.
Principal to which to grant specified permissions. Using this parameter means setting permissions on a resource.
Principal domain such as computer name or authority to which principal applies
Access control type to either allow or deny specified rights
Defines registry access rights to use for principal when creating access and audit rules. The default includes: ReadKey Where, ReadKey: QueryValues, Notify, EnumerateSubKeys and ReadPermissions

Inheritance flags specify the semantics of inheritance for access control entries. This parameter is ignored for leaf objects, such as files or or registry entries. This parameter controls the "Applies to" column in advanced security dialog The default is "This folder, subfolders and files"

Specifies how Access Control Entries (ACEs) are propagated to child objects. These flags are significant only if inheritance flags are present, (when Inheritance is not "None") This parameter is ignored for leaf objects, such as files or or registry entries. This parameter affects the "Applies to" column in advanced security dialog

If set, preserve inherited access rules, which become explicit rules. The default is to remove inherited access rules. This parameter is ignored if Protected is not set. This parameter controls choices offered after "Enable/Disable Inheritance" button.
If specified, applies specified operations to all subobjects. This parameter is ignored for Leaf objects, such as files or registry entries.

If specified, removes all explicit access rules and keeps only inherited. if "Protected" parameter is specified inherited rules are removed as well. If "Protected" is specified with "PreserveInheritance", then the inherited rules become explicit rules and everything else is removed.
If specified skips prompting for confirmation.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

If set, preserve inherited access rules, which become explicit rules. The default is to remove inherited access rules. This parameter is ignored if Protected is not set. This parameter controls choices offered after "Enable/Disable Inheritance" button.

Defines file system access rights to use for principal when creating access and audit rules. The default includes: ReadAndExecute, ListDirectory and Traverse Where: 1. ReadAndExecute: Read and ExecuteFile 2. Read: ReadData, ReadExtendedAttributes, ReadAttributes, and ReadPermissions.

This parameter affects the "Applies to" column in advanced security dialog

maml:alert.maml:para: TODO: Manage audit entries TODO: Which combination is for "Replace all child object permissions with inheritable permissions from this object" TODO: Which combination is for "Include inheritable permissions from this object's parent" Set-Permission function is a wrapper around *-Acl commandlets for easier ACL editing. This function also serves as replacement for takeown.exe and icacls.exe whose syntax is strange and using these in PowerShell is usually awkward. TODO: See https://powershellexplained.com/2020-03-15-Powershell-shouldprocess-whatif-confirm-shouldcontinue-everything/ TODO: switch to ignore errors and continue doing things, useful for recurse TODO: A bunch of other security options can be implemented TODO: Set-Acl : Requested registry access is not allowed, unable to modify ownership happens because PowerShell process does not have high enough privileges even if run as Administrator, a fix for this is in Scripts\External\Set-Privilege.ps1 which this function must make use of.
Links listed below are provided for additional parameter description in order of how parameters are declared

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets function defaults for user SomeUser on path D:\SomePath
Only "Remote Management Users" have permissions on "D:\SomePath", other entries are removed
LanmanServer service is denied specified rights for specified directory and all it's contents
Allows to ReadAndExecute, ListDirectory and Traverse to "SomeFolder" and it's contents for COMPUTERNAME\SomeUser

maml:description.maml:para: Set vertical screen buffer to recommended value

Set-ScreenBuffer sets screenbuffer for current powershell session. In some cases, depending on project settings a user might need larger buffer to preserve all the output in the console for review and scroll back.

maml:Description.maml:para: Sets screen buffer height to specified value
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Sets screen buffer height to specified value
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to Set-ScreenBuffer
None. Set-ScreenBuffer does not generate any output

maml:description.maml:para: Update context for Approve-Execute function
Script scope context variable is updated. Execution context is shown in the console every time Approve-Execute is called. It helps to know the state and progress of execution.

maml:Description.maml:para: First context string before . (dot)
Second context string after . (dot)
Additional string after -> (arrow)
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Additional string after -> (arrow)
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
